Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: A critical call reports a multi-vehicle collision on a highway outside the city.
Story: I sat in the break room, nervously glancing at the clock. My mentor had set aside this hour just for me, a rare chance to ask questions and learn from her experience. She’d emphasized how important it was to respect her time, and I didn’t want to let her down. I’d prepared a list of questions, determined to make the most of it. Just as I was about to head to her office, my radio crackled to life: “All available units, multi-vehicle collision, Highway 17, possible critical injuries.” My heart pounded. As an ambulance driver, I knew every second counted. The expectation was clear—drop everything and respond. But if I left now, I’d be disrespecting my mentor’s time, maybe even missing my only chance this week. I stood frozen, torn between the urgent call of duty and the commitment I’d made to my mentor, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
